newsitem.title: JAPAN: Regional Japan broker applies for liquidation.
newsitem.headline: Regional Japan broker applies for liquidation.

text.p: A regional Japanese broker affiliated with Yamaichi Securities Co Ltd said on Friday it had filed a bankruptcy application after huge losses in speculative margin trading.
Ogawa Securities, based in Osaka, said it had filed with the Finance Ministry to discontinue operations, after Yamaichi refused it financial aid.
If the application is accepted, Ogawa would become the first brokerage to go bankrupt in Japan in 17 years.
Ogawa's business has been in trouble due to a stock market slump following the bursting of Japan's asset-inflated "bubble" economy of the late 1980s.
Its condition worsened after it suffered losses from speculative margin trading earlier this year.

Japan's Kyodo news agency said Tokuo Namba, president of Ogawa Securities, told a news conference in Osaka that he was responsible for the decision to get involved in the speculative trades which brought about the huge losses.
Yamaichi, one of Japan's "Big Four" brokers, said that it would still provide funds to protect Ogawa customers.
Ogawa's clients may also get protection from the joint deposit insurance system, a fund set up in 1968 from donations from about 150 member brokerages, the fund's chairman said in a statement.

Yamaichi vice president Ryuji Shirai told a news conference: "Considering Ogawa's huge loss, its financial condition and earning power, we cannot expect Ogawa's financial standing to improve greatly even if we provide support."
Shirai said continuing to give assistance to Ogawa would also be "a great risk" for Yamaichi.
Before applying for liquidation, Ogawa will write off the losses using two billion yen ($17.2 million) to be presented from the investor protection fund, Finance Ministry officials said. ($1=116 yen)
